107734.question: what is the little roll into a snare hit called? What is a good way to imitate that purely with midi and samples?
107734.answer: it might be called a "ruff" well, one way is to just get a recording (sample) of someone actually playing that. but the problem there is, it's not very 'playable' for you because you won't have good control over when the final attack is. so if you want something usable, you'll want a steady sample of a continuous drum roll, with fast attack and fast release, so it starts and stops immediately when you press or lift the key, and then you'll want a separate sample, on another key, for a normal snare hit. and then you can play both keys to time the ruffs any way you want. And of course, for decent results, you'll want to make them both dynamic sensitive, and have many different versions of the sample, for different loudness levels, and also many different versions for the same loudness level, so they don't all sound identical

107828.question: im trying to organize a few hundred sounds by "type", and ive got all the "percussive" stuff on in pile (where the pitch doesn't matter) but i'm not sure what the call the other pile, any good names for non-percussive musical sounds? (pianos, guitars, horns, synths, basses)
107828.answer: besides drums and perc, the 3 categories i use are 'BASS', 'VOC', and 'NON'. bass means bass, voc means my voice, and non means anything besides voc bass drums or perc. These are the functional categories i use for mixing, and for that purpose the category devisions are nearly rock solid. Within the non, there's always a vague attempt to find some categories for arrangement purposes, but the lines always get blurred and break down and argue about how specific to be or not. lead, pno, rhodes, organ, bell, guit, strings, twinkle, pluck, pad, flute, syn, horn, trumpet, miscnon, ..... as you can see there would be a lot of overlap and many things can be used for both, so there never seems to be clarity on that level. i've noticed the same thing when trying to deal with the categorization of my website. at a certain point you just have to accept that real life ultimately will resist total categorization, yet always seems to invite you to try

107840.question: how the heck long is an interior diagonal line of a cube
107840.answer: let's see..... leg squared plus leg squared equals hypotenuse squared...... so let's start with the square face... call the edge 1. 1+1= hypotenuse squared, so the hypotenuse diagonal across the face is √2. Then i can imagine another right triangle with that hypotenuse, the outer edge of the cube, and the grand diagonal (the one you're looking for). so it should be 1 squared plus √2 squared equals answer squared.... 1 plus (root 2 squared) is 3.... the answer should be the square root of 3. If one edge of the cube is 1, then the grand diagonal should be the square root of 3

108173.question: Why did the orange shirt guy duck under the sign
108173.answer: logistically, that was the only solution i could come up with to get to the right place at the right time. this is one of those puzzles that turns up when you actually get to the set. purple character climbs straight down and looks at the sign. orange character needs to immediately get to a vantage point of looking across the storefronts, while saying the next line. there are many 'bad' ways to do this. orange could climb down and walk directly through purple's line of sight.... this would seem to break purple's concentration. if orange climbs down and walks forward and around back of purple, this goes in between purple and the camera, which is distracting. another possibility is that orange could sort of slide to the side, on the sign, before jumping down. but that seems cumbersome and pointless. i also considered having orange jump off the back of the sign. but it would happen so quickly, i decided that that would look too much like accidental fall. climbing under the sign seemed to be the best way to solve all of this. with the added bonus that maybe he found the extra 'R' letters in the bushes there, under the sign

108192.question: could you elaborate on the 'dos and donts of speech bubble placement'?
108192.answer: sure. when the camera is very far away, obviously the speech bubble needs to be huge in the scene, in order to be a reasonable size on screen. And it needs to point directly to the characters. but the problem that sometimes happens is, there might be a tree or something closer to the camera than the character, which occupies the screenspace where the speech bubble goes. so if you put the speech bubble in the right place on the screen, it will either be partially obscured by the tree, or, it will disobey the laws of occlusion and be in front of the tree when it shouldn't be. I discovered that, if the camera is totally still, in most cases, you can get away with this. in other words, you can put a speech bubble which appears to point to the character on the 2D screenspace, even if its 3D placement would be impossible. in reality, it's actually a much smaller speech bubble, much closer to the camera, and its position is adjusted so it looks like it points to the character, even though if it were actually next to the character it would be behind the tree. So i've learned that you can usually get away with that when the camera is totally still. But when the camera is slightly moving, this absolutely does not work. There is a shot in the most recent video where the camera is across the street, looking toward the characters through the trees. To put the speech bubble actually next to the characters, it would be entirely obscured by the trees. If i cheat the speech bubble and put it in front of the trees, but smaller, this is a disaster because the camera is drifting slightly, and it becomes glaringly obvious that the bubble is much closer to the camera. So i tried to linearly keyframe the speech bubble to stay positioned next to the character, in 2D screen space. This is an even bigger disaster, and it looks like the scene is broken because the bubble is behaving as if it should be behind the tree, but it actually obscures the tree. Then i tried it with the speech bubble in the same place, but a longer stem reaching mostly back away from the camera toward the character. again, with the drifting camera, as the shape of the speech bubble is revealed, it looks truly bizarre. i ended up having place the bubble far off to the right, outside the trees, and make a very long tail on the 2D plane. which looks a little ridiculous and i didn't really want to do it that way, but i tried absolutely every other way, and it's the only thing that seemed to work. And i've also seen it done in comic books, so it's probably the best way

108686.question: the argument that saying "this apple is similar" and "are we in a simulation" is the same since you're not clarifying what the other thing is is not valid because simulation is a noun and similar is an adjective
108686.answer: that's not the basis of the analogy. the basis of the analogy was that they both require a partner. actually, to play into your love of grammar, i might add that they both specifically seem to require a prepositional phrase, in that instance. i can also give you another example of how a noun+preposition can behave exactly the same way as adj+preposition: if you say you are "a fan of" something, or if you say you are "wild about" something. on paper, "a fan" appears to be a noun, and "wild" appears to be an adjective, and yet i think you can see that those phrases seem to occupy the exact same grammatical real estate

108724.question: is your screenwriting process very linear, or do your scripts go through multiple passes? i know you've shared the original draft for the rabbit video along with the updated "final" script, but even the "final" script is different from the video. e.g., your omission of: 1. (person has looked at the caption, to his upper right) 2. damn, 3. phone: 'have you tried going on the internet'? what informs these decisions? how exactly does your process look like? how do you edit the original draft; i.e., do you go through it over and over from beginning to end, or do you "jump around," so to speak, or a mix of both? thanks
108724.answer: i would prefer not to keep editing it, because i think the first way is usually the most genuine. it gets tricky when you try to pull things apart from the inside....... but what can you do. if part of it sucks, then you gotta get into some surgery and pray for a good outcome it should be noted that the 'have you tried going on the internet' has a dash - written at the beginning of the line. that is my notation for this line is cut (cancelled). so that decision was already made. For the person looking at the caption, to the right, .... well, i think i just forgot to do that. Quite often, and i'm not proud of this, quite often i notice after i've finished producing a video, if i look back at the script there are various nuances that just got forgotten. Usually that's because once i've recorded the audio for the vocal, i don't check the script again. perhaps i should. Or, maybe, in this case, it might be the result of the fact that i went with a full-screen separate card for that announcement, so it wouldn't make any sense to have the character look at it. If someone had made me aware of that detail, i may have decided not to do it anyway i don't make any changes unless i have to. i just do a full readthrough, and if there are any parts that just really make me miserable, then inevitably something has to be done, somehow

108739.question: how about a blur effect when your characters and 3d objects move at really fast speeds?
108739.answer: i can't think of a way to feasibly achieve that. i put some thought about it when i did the scene with the all the cars rushing by. the basic idea that comes to mind is, for that scene, i'd have to speed up the frame rate to about 10,000 times what it normally would be. and then i'd have to composite each final frame (at normal frame rate) to be a blend of the 5000 frames before and after it. i'd be willing to do that, but it would probably take several years just to do one shot. even if the whole process were completely automated, it would still take an absurdly long time even on a supercomputer. so for that reason, that method is out of the question. i also did some thinking about what other gimmicks i can do artistically to sort of give an impression of that effect. and i didn't really have any bright ideas about it, but what i decided to do first is just render the cars moving without blur and take a look at it. i actually thought it looked great without the blur, so i didn't have to worry about adding the blur. and of course, in that shot, i'm glad there's no blur because this way you can actually see the cars in detail

108740.question: what is that song you made about soft clothing about actually?
108740.answer: it's about seeing how all these country songs have these awesome titles, sometimes long titles, where the title itself has entertainment value baked right in. i've felt envious about that all my life, just thinking, wow, what a joy it must be to write like that. and i guess for years i never got around to trying it because i was always busy with other types of songwriting experiments. but eventually i got around to it, and i tried doing it, just coming up with the title first, with no music. several things got added to the writing queue, and then in due time some of them eventually got musicified, and then in due time some of them have been completed and recorded. other examples include "mount saint helens is about to blow up, and i'm having a fine swell day", "the moon is made of cheese but i can't taste it", "the easter bunny told me that christmas isn't real but santa claus is still jesus", "the best thing about games is losing them", and many more titles still in the queue

108794.question: Could you share your rules of capital letter usage?
108794.answer: it's not perfectly defined, but some of the general principles are: chord symbols are always capitalized (except for "b" when it's used to mean "flat"). Acronyms are almost always capitalized. the letter L is often capitalized whenever it would otherwise be in danger of being confused for I or 1. the letter "i" when referrring to self is never capitalized. the start of sentences may occasionally need to be capitalized if i feel there is a tone change, or if there should be a decisive break in between sentences, OR if there seems to be a lot of other punctuation in the area and it would otherwise be unclear that it's the start of a new sentence. It's used for emphasis, the same way bold would be used, and the reason i prefer capitals instead of bold is because it's much more likely that the capitals will actually show up on any device, where as bold might get lost somehow. And also if i'm just simply referring to the letter itself, such as the letter F, it is most often capitalized, because that is probably the way that most people think of individual letters. The exception to that, of course, would be the letter "i", which, again, for similar reasons to why L sometimes gets capitalized more often, "i" should be capitalized less often because, similarly, it runs the risk of being confused with l or 1. I also often use capitalization for signage, especially with short contents, such as "STOP" or "EXIT", especially when i am trying to replicate signage that people are familiar with in the outside world

108833.question: What do you do for the non-musical sound design?
108833.answer: sometimes i use percussion sounds, but what i did on the juggling video was i made a checklist of all the moments in the video that needed sounds, then took a bunch of objects from around the house and brought them into the booth and tried making all the sounds i could get from them, and checking things off the list when i thought i had something that worked for each sound needed in the video. sometimes i ended up getting a sound that worked for a different bit than i thought that particular object would be used for. i also discovered that i could actually get a wide variety of different sounds just by tapping my fingers and hands together in different ways, in different proximities to the microphone. In videos since then, i haven't recorded any more sounds, i've just gone back to the recording session for the juggling video and i've been able to get whatever i need from there

108898.question: how do you read drum notation, help
108898.answer: it's just rhythms, and the instruments should be labeled. if not, then it might be for drum kit (drum set) in which case the X's near the top of the staff are cymbals, the regular noteheads near the bottom of the staff should be the kick, and the snare is probably a regular notehead on the upper middle space. the rest of the mid staff (with regular noteheads) should usually be toms. if you see + and o above the hh, that means closed or open. But these things should be labeled at the beginning of the chart, because not all of this is standardized

109543.question: hi bill, i think i need some advice. i have a synthesizer that i would like to use to make my own music. the problem is that i don't have a daw besides audacity, which i have heard has limitations. almost everyone i look up to uses some variation of logic, but i feel like completely switching to a new os would be even more of a problem. speaking of that, i really don't even have a usable computer because mine is very bad and freezes up trying to load a browser let alone handle a daw or a video editor. anyway i guess i am here to see if you have any advice? i have all these ideas but no way to document them really, and it's getting to be a lot
109543.answer: this could be a blessing. maybe you can find 1 sound in the keyboard and then learn to just play it while singing at the same time. and then record that on 1 microphone, like the one on your phone. there's a lot you probably want to learn about yourself and how you make music, and usually it's best to just start with the simplest thing that's available. you don't even know what you want yet, and the advantage with using exactly what you have is it's probably a unique set of tools that aren't exactly what any other person has. you're gonna have a unique sound automatically. it reminds me of that guy that lived next to a spatula, so he made spatula music. there's not very much spatula music out there, so, someone's gotta do it

109551.question: thoughts on 6/4 time? someone told me no one makes songs in 6/4
109551.answer: a lot of people do it without knowing it. they'll put 3/4 on the page and have tiny bars when it really might have been better to say 6/4. there's no reason 'we wish you a merry christmas', 'happy birthday', 'you make me feel like a natural woman', and trillions of other popular songs from every generation wouldn't really be better off saying 6/4 on the page. or, depending on the tempo, be converted to 6/8 or even written as 4/4 and put everything in triplets. a lot of different notation options for songs in 3-feels. But songs with a 4-feel tend to just use 4/4 because it's all groups of 4 within groups of 4 within groups of 4, so 4/4 will always fit. I'd say about 20% of songs use some kind of 3-feel, and within that you're going to have a million different ways of writing the same thing. so those time signatures (6/4, 6/8, etc) would appear less common, but they are used for the same type of music which again i'd say comprises at least 10% of music from all generations

109554.question: i really want to get more into jazz . could you send any recommendations my way
109554.answer: the word jazz makes my head explode because it means like 12,000 different things over the past 100 years. it all comes down to what made you ask this. what you're really looking for is probably whatever it was at that exact moment that made you think you want this. For example, let's say the reason you are asking this is because last night you walked past a music venue that said "jazz" on it, and it made you feel good for whatever reason and that's what made you think that what you're looking for is probably called 'jazz'. Or maybe you met a cool person who told you they like 'jazz'. Either way, your best option is to recall the scenario that inspired this desire, and go back there and you'll probably find a trail of bread crumbs from there to your next destination

109573.answer: usually not like that, although a lot of people do it that way and i suppose it goes ok. What i do instead is write the whole thing together. it plays better to my strengths when i am able to custom write all the music to bend at the will of the lyric/melody. it's all written as one. you never know when you're gonna need the entire band to ditch into another section suddenly at bar 3 and a half, on a whim, based on some unexpected mention of the papacy or something

109575.question: thoughts on kalimbas? they're these instruments that are also called lamellophones or plucked idiophones. highest amount of keys is about 21, and the smallest is about 5. i have one with 17 keys and honestly it's fun to play. it's like a mix between a xylophone and piano in a way, you play with your fingers, but mainly the nails, but you also have metal keys. anyways, back to you bill.
109575.answer: i don't know anything about them physically, aside from what you just told me. But i know all about what they sound like, and i use the sound for similar situations as things like xylophone or marimba. the kalimba sounds similar but usually there is a bit of a 'fuzz' or rattle sound to it. it probably shows up in just about every arrangement i put out, because there are always several of them in my repository and i tend to like the sound and find it useful. then again, i think there are also some other instruments i have which sound similar but are named differently. my arrangement process usually does not involve looking up instruments by name

109579.question: 1.16.23 5:41 pm I wasn't the original asker of this question...but do you think in these types of situations, the time sig is just about what is easiest to write/read on a page? Or is there a feel difference? Like, as a drummer, would you play differently for a song that was notated as 3/4 vs 6/4?
109579.answer: sure. although a lot of people make weird choices........ 3/4 is more popular but that usually makes the bars tiny (depending on the tempo). because most songs with a 3-feel have the little beats going by at a much faster tempo than quarter notes would usually be. on the other hand, if you consider the whole group of 3 as one beat, you can use 4/4 and put the whole thing in triplets. but that would actually make the bars 4 times longer. possibly too long. in these situations where 3/4 is too tiny and 4/4 with triplets is too long, i usually go with 6/8, which keeps the note values at about the speed you'd expect them to be, and it keeps the bar size at a comfortable speed of about 2 or 3 seconds per bar, as it probably would be in most 4/4 songs you'd never know until you get to know the song. it's like the difference between people named jamie and people named jerry

109653.question: so let's say you have a the number 0.444444444 repeating infinitely. infinitely EXCEPT you're told that the number 5 MIGHT be in the digits somewhere. you don't know if the number 5 is anywhere in there, but you have to completely round it to the nearest whole number. if there's a 5 somewhere in there, then all the 4s before it correct to a 5 and it ends up rounding to a 1. but if there isn't, the 4s remain and it rounds to a 0. you don't have infinite time to check for the 5. what do you round it to, 0 or 1?
109653.answer: what? what? clearly 0. there's no reason to round it to 1 unless you are following some bizzaro rounding rules. the number is significantly closer to 1, no matter what. .44445, .445, .45, heck even .4999999 are unambiguously closer to 1. the only way that .4444444444445 could possibly end up as 1 is if the number is being rounded 1 digit at a time, over and over again, destructively. and if that happens then the process needs to be fixed because that's a serious corruption. rounding the entire number at once, it unquestionably goes down. there's no rule in the world that says even .45 should go to one, any more than 45 should go to 100. again, the only way 45 goes to 100 is if one person rounded 45 to 50 and then handed it off to someone else without telling them that it came from 45 and then that second person took the new 50 and rounded it to 100. in which case, again, there is a serious communication breakdown here which is corrupting the results and should be investigated

109692.question: how do i force myself to stop noodling around in the daw and actually make a god DAMN SONG
109692.answer: try this: write the song somewhere else. then you will be nimble enough to imagine how the song goes, overall, without being plagued with all the exact details of how to build it. you will be free, to imagine it going any way you want. focus on what *happens*. how it will be perceived. see what you're capable of imagining, and see if you can find a writing system that allows you to explain that on the page. Then once you know how the song goes, then hit the studio and then you'll be on a mission

109693.question: I heard a song in a dream last night, and it was great (I think). The issue is that I didn't wake up immediately, so by the time I woke up I could only recall vague ideas of what I think it went like, and it felt very underwhelming compared to what it felt like in my dream. Has this happened to you? I'd love a bulletproof way to always wake up immediately after hearing a song, but not so soon that it doesn't have time to finish (which has also happened to me), but I'm not sure if that's possible
109693.answer: yes they're hard to catch. the more time you spend writing and coming up with things while you're awake, the easier it will be to remember and understand what you hear in your dreams. and it will also generally increase the chances that the good stuff will also come around while you're awake

109758.question: I accidentally came up with a super cool melody with awesome chords... but no lyrics. What do you recommend I do here? I worry that anything I come up with will feel forced
109758.answer: it's there. if the melody and chords really are super cool, then there is a lyricized version that does work. there are a few tricks to help hone in on it. gather the tiny details that you think you know, or almost know. For example: maybe you know a certain word works really well for part of it, for example let's say the word 'banana' just sounds perfect for the last part of it. Or, maybe you know banana sounds great for that part but you doubt it should be about bananas. Add that factoid to your list of factoids, regardless. write down that you love the word banana at the end but you're not sure if it could work. See if you can hone in on any other things you know, about other tiny parts of it. What can you rule out? what can you rule in? Here's another exercise: just start coming up with as many phoenecically functional things as possible that fit, without regard for what you want it to mean. This will help you notice things: for example you might notice that 80% of the results are phrased as a question. You may notice that these 2 little notes there are always either "in the" or "and it". You may notice that certain phrases keep fitting a certain part, over and over. Now, on the other side of the coin, here's a totally different exercise to try: paraphrase the whole feeling of it, without the melody. so just write down, in as many words as you like, what you think the melody is saying, without worrying about how many words or syllables you use. anything you can grasp onto. maybe you think it has a feeling of freshness. maybe you think it has a feeling of 'morning'. maybe you think it has a feeling of sorrow. maybe you think it has a feeling of good news. write down as much as you can about what you think the melody feels like. Then, maybe certain key words will pop out at you that possibly DO fit. And most importantly, regardless of whether any of this works, going through all this makes it much more likely that the answer will actually just fall on your head later when you're not even thinking about it

109863.question: in 1.20.21 4:10 am , you say that 3D was about to ruin your whole life; how so?
109863.answer: around august 2020, i had gone so far down the rabbit hole of programing, experimenting, and planning, that i suddenly realized there is no end in sight. i'd spent the previous few months working character animation (it was then that i modeled and developed the rig and character animation system i still use today) and i was just doing test videos where a person is talking for 5 or 10 minutes (not me, just random clips i found from interviews. some of them were actually foreign languages just for the heck of it) to hone in on my abilities to animate a character talking, gesturing, etc. and somewhere along the line i decided it's probably a good idea to make some teeth appear and disappear in the mouth, to make the letter "F" (or "V", etc) jump out a bit more. so, somewhere in the midst of trying to develop the F-teeth scheme, i realized there was no end to how deep this goes and i jumped hastily out of the rabbit hole and directly into the song/video writing and selection process to prepare the next actual video for production and release

109864.question: has music always/ever been your calling? how did you discover it if it was? cheers from the guy who has asked various questions regarding not having hobbies

109869.question: hi bill, i'm starting to get into songwriting in the opposite way you did, where i'm writing songs before learning an instrument. like to write songs, i'm essentially singing the melody-lyric and tapping out a rhythm into the microphone, and writing down the lyrics so i remember them. this comes very easy to me, way easier than it does for you, like i can pretty much immediately come up with the next part of the song easily after listening / reading it through, or even just thinking about the song off-handedly, as long as i have enough mental energy (which hasn't been that often until recently due to my chronic illness, but that's another story entirely). it hasn't taken me much longer than like a couple hours or so to finish writing any of my full-length (like 2-3 minute) songs so far, one of them was even written in a half hour and i still really like it, although i haven't finished more than like 10 or 15 (i haven't counted yet), and my almost-finished songs have been at a similar pace too. as i've started. so the songwriting is going fantastic so far. anyways i'm getting off track, the problem is, i have little to no experience with any musical instrument, and know no way of coming up with chords other than entering the melody notes in a website to figure out the scale, looking up the notes & chords in that scale, and hoping for the best. do you have any tips for me to get better at using the instrument and learning how chords work naturally? since i know that's how you learned yours, and had pretty much the exact opposite problems as me when it came to writing & recording songs, so i wondered if you had any tips for a beginner approaching music in the opposite order as you, as a pretty confident songwriter only now approaching the instrument hurdle as a necessary way to get things recorded. thabks
109869.answer: that's not really the opposite of how i do it. that's very similar to how i do it it comes easy for me too me too most often the best ones are the quickest just grab a keyboard and start playing with it. it's just like language. the only great way to learn it is to just jump in and start using it many many years ago maybe, but then i learned to push the instrumentalist out of the way and just write the song instead, and life got a lot more fun. one of the biggest breakthroughs was to do it away from the instrument. like in the library using only paper i'm not buying this whole opposite theory you have, but, .... think about this.... if it really is the opposite way, then how could i have any tips for that? it sounds like you think things are much easier for you than for me, and if that is the case then you should probably be giving me tips instruments are like langauges. just grab one and start living in it. you might be scared at how 'long it takes', but you can keep going forever and keep learning. the progress never stops, and it starts immediately, as soon as you first see the instrument

109874.question: 1.29.23 5:17 am yeah it does, it lands on the one at the same time as 'world' in 'and I'm dreaming of a brand new world', maybe I should have said two bars later not one bar later sorry
109874.answer: it's not there, but you're gonna make me open it up and prove it. the flute has absolutely zero notes or sound after the end of bar 15 (where the riff is). but here are some audio clips to investigate whatever you actually are hearing, on the & of 4 ('world') in bar 16. (and for those of you counting along at home, the song starts on bar 2, with the pickup "i'm" being at the end of bar 1). so here is 6 beats starting from the top of the bar "dreaming of a brand new world", as is in the final mix: frontdoorbar16. And here is the same exact time range with the vocal muted: frontdoorbar16novoc. (i can already tell it's gonna be the rhodes). And here is the exact same time range with the drums and bass also muted: frontdoorbar16nodrbass. Here is just the "world" moment, with voc, drums, and bass muted: frontdoorworldnodrbass. it's getting more and more obvious, i think, that the only culprit here for what you've been hearing is the rhodes chord because it's the only thing playing that note at that time. but i'll give you each of the 3 instruments here individually anyway. 109958.question: if i wanted to improve my improvisation and/or songwriting, would it be useful to learn a new chord every day and see how it feels when played after/before/between/instead of other chords?
109958.answer: no. i think doing this will trick you into becoming very uninspired, because a chord includes everything about how/when/where it was used, in the actual song or piece of music. And there's infinite hows/whens/wheres. and each of those things makes everything different about what the chord does. so what i'm saying is, you'll never be able to get a list of all those. So if you say you're gonna "learn a chord" every day, that implies that you're going to be getting them from some list, but there is no list. because it's infinite and there's no order. and some of them are the same, but all of them are the same and different from each other at the same time. Anyway, my point is, the only way to get chords is to either find them how they've already been used in music you know in love, or make them up entirely. so if you're doing it that way, then i think it could be cool. Anyway, for your situation i think i'd recommend 2 different things: 1 is songs/music. just study all the songs/music you actually know and love, and see what they're doing with chords. i think right now you might be expecting it to look like a shelf full of a cereal boxes, lined up like soldiers. but it's really not like that at all, and it's much more like a room full of furniture. that's the best way i can describe it. so if you're learning 1 "piece" of furniture per day, it's gonna be hard enough just to figure out what counts as 1 piece and what counts as 5. or what counts as just the space between the other furniture. anyway, i think you'll see what i mean once you dive into all your favorite songs. and there's another thing i would suggest, that's totally the opposite of studying songs. Just spend some separate time just going nuts on the instrument with a total blank canvas and no song or anything, total free time, next to an open window, and just let the demons fly right in. this is where you make up your own way of doing things. your own way of spending time, on the instrument. Just act like you're sitting in a giant barrel of untapped TIME. time to play any note, not play any note, or combination, for as long or not long as you can imagine. sometimes when doing this, using the pitch bend a little bit can be insanely helpful. just playing notes and tweaking the bend up and down by very small amounts while you play, can be an amazing way to cheat your way into that magic zone of actually feeling like you've just played exactly what you meant to play. and then that supercharges you into very quickly and genuinely discovering all kinds of relationships/intervals/shapes. maybe because it unearths the pitches just enough from their *absolute* location and then suddenly the relationships come alive and become way more potent. It's kind of like when you're eating a cake and you're not sure whether you're tasting the cake or just tasting the cake's location. then you move the cake 3 inches to the left and try the cake again, suddenly you have a more keen awareness of what the cake tastes like, regardless of its location

109977.question: (in C Lydian) the notes played together are C, E, and F#. what do you call this chord? it can't be C(b5) because F# is the fourth of Lydian and not the fifth, and because i can add a G right next to the F# and i'll be damned if that G is an Abb
109977.answer: sure it can i suppose you have a choice: Cmaj(b5), and i promise you there is nothing illegal about calling it that. it happens normally in the real world. (and you can still use F# on the staff in the melody if it goes there). Or, if you insist on preserving the "#4" aspect in the chord symbol, you can say Cmaj(add#4,no5). Although i guarantee if you use the second choice on a chart and give it to a player, you are much much more likely to get a pause and confused looks on the first runthrough. where as if you use Cmaj(b5) it increases the chances significantly that they will actually play what you wanted, the first time through. Sure, it's nice to adhere to proper scale numbering / good enharmonics when you can, but sooner or later you run into edge cases where you have to submit to F#=Gb. There are many more extreme cases, but this is an important one that seems to hit home for you

109998.answer: sometimes yes i think it's a fair idea. as i was saying, music loves to strike unexpectedly. and it seems you're already analyzing whether you should or should not continue if you are not 'feeling it'. So therefore, it becomes a good idea to continue anyway, because, again, that increases the likelihood that you will forget how hard you're trying

109999.question: what to do when what i want to do in the future keeps changing? i have less time to decide and plan the more my future changes
109999.answer: enjoy the ride. if you've ever been on one of the non-changing timelines you'll recall it's excrutiating
